010package imagingbook.common.noise.hashing;
011
012import java.util.Random;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * Abstract superclass of various hash functions. It cannot be
017 * instantiated directly, but its subclasses can. Two static methods
018 * {@code create()} and {@code create(seed)} are provided for convenience.
019 * Typical use:
020 * </p>
021 * <pre>
022 * HashFun hf = new HashFun.create(); // or, alternatively,
023 * HashFun hf = new Hash32Ward(seed);
024 * double g = hf.hash(u); // g is in [-1,+1]
025 * double g = hf.hash(u, v);
026 * double[] g = hf.hash(u, v, w);
027 * </pre>
028 * <p>
029 * Omit seed in the constructor call to get a random seed hash function of the
030 * specified type.
031 * </p>
032 */
033public abstract class HashFun {
034        
035        private static final Random rand = new Random();
036        int seed;
037        
038        protected HashFun() {
039                this.seed = makeRandomSeed();
040        }
041        
042        protected HashFun(int seed){
043                this.seed = seed;
044        }
045        
046        /**
047         * @return A new HashFun object.
048         * Has32Shift is used as the default type.
049         */
050        public static HashFun create() {
051                return new Hash32Shift();
052        }
053        
054        /**
055         * Creates a new {@link HashFun} object initialized with seed. 
056         * Has32Shift is used as the default type.
057         * 
058         * @param seed the seed
059         * @return a new {@link HashFun} object
060         */
061        public static HashFun create(int seed) {
062                return new Hash32Shift(seed);
063        }
064        
065        protected int makeRandomSeed() {
066                return 0x000fffff & rand.nextInt();
067        }
068        
069        // these hash functions return either a single value or a vector 
070        // with elements in [0,1]
071        public abstract double hash(int u);                                     // 1D hash function
072        public abstract double[] hash(int u, int v);            // 2D hash function
073        public abstract double[] hash(int u, int v, int w);     // 3D hash function
074        public abstract double[] hash(int[] p);                         // ND hash function
075
076}
077
078
